item.title: How AI Is Transforming Security & Coding in 2025
item.description: Artificial Intelligence is revolutionizing both security and software development. Here’s what’s new in 2025:
item.content:encoded:
Artificial Intelligence is revolutionizing both security and software development. Here’s what’s new in 2025:

AI for Security Scanning​

Modern tools like Vibe Security Suite use AI to:

  • Detect vulnerabilities in real time
  • Prioritize critical issues based on context
  • Reduce false positives so you can focus on what matters

AI-Assisted Coding​

Developers now rely on AI for:

  • Secure code suggestions
  • Automated code reviews
  • Learning best practices as they work

Practical Tips​

  • Integrate AI-powered scans into your CI/CD pipeline
  • Use Vibe Security CLI locally to catch issues before pushing code
  • Stay up to date with the latest AI-driven security advisories

Want to share your experience with AI and security? Reach out to the Vibe Security Suite team or contribute your own post!

  • Security Trends in 2025: Open Source, Dev-First, and AI

item.title: Security Trends in 2025: Open Source, Dev-First, and AI
item.description: Welcome to the Vibe Security Suite blog! In 2025, the security landscape is evolving faster than ever. Here are the top trends shaping the year:
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the Vibe Security Suite blog! In 2025, the security landscape is evolving faster than ever. Here are the top trends shaping the year:

1. Open Source Security Goes Mainstream​

Open source security tools are now the backbone of modern development. Projects like Vibe Security Suite empower teams to adopt best practices without vendor lock-in.

2. Developer-First Security​

Security is shifting left—developers are running scans locally and in CI/CD, catching issues before code even reaches production.

3. AI-Powered Threat Detection​

AI and machine learning are now essential for identifying threats at scale. From code analysis to anomaly detection, AI is everywhere.

Stay tuned for more insights, tutorials, and updates from the Vibe Security community!

Read more:

  • Welcome to the Vibe Security Suite Blog!
  • How AI Is Transforming Security & Coding in 2025

item.title: Building Interactive Security Dashboards with MDX & React (2025)
item.description: In 2025, security dashboards are more interactive than ever—thanks to MDX and React! With Vibe Security Suite, you can embed live components, charts, and even trigger scans directly from your documentation or blog.
item.content:encoded:
In 2025, security dashboards are more interactive than ever—thanks to MDX and React! With Vibe Security Suite, you can embed live components, charts, and even trigger scans directly from your documentation or blog.

tip

MDX lets you mix Markdown and React. Build dynamic security dashboards or embed live scan results right in your docs!

Here’s a simple example—an interactive button to trigger a (simulated) security scan:

<button onClick={() => alert('Vibe Security Scan started!')}>Run Security Scan</button>

Want to learn more? Check out our CLI usage guide or contribute your own MDX-powered dashboard!

item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the official Vibe Security Suite blog! Here you'll find updates on open-source security, developer-first tools, and the latest trends in AI-driven security for 2025 and beyond.

Stay tuned for tutorials, release notes, and community highlights. We're excited to have you join us on this journey to make security accessible, powerful, and open for everyone.

Read more:

  • Security Trends in 2025: Open Source, Dev-First, and AI
  • How AI Is Transforming Security & Coding in 2025

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

  • 2019-05-30-welcome.md
  • 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

The blog supports tags as well!

And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.
